docs.lead_paragraph: Betsy McCaughey Ross caught Peter F. Vallone off guard yesterday in their final debate before Tuesday's Democratic primary for governor, challenging his responses in a questionnaire on abortion, answers that she said contradicted his public statements on the issue. In the last five days, Ms. McCaughey Ross, the Lieutenant Governor, has taken to attacking Mr. Vallone, who leads in the polls, and questioning his commitment to abortion rights. Yesterday's exchange was the closest that any of his rivals have come in six televised debates to truly rattling Mr. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker.

headline.main: McCaughey Ross Rattles Vallone in Heated Debate

docs.abstract: Betsy McCaughey Ross catches Peter F Vallone off guard in their final debate before Tuesday's Democratic primary for governor, challenging his responses in questionnaire on abortion, answers that she says contradicts his public statements on issue; Vallone responds that he did not recognize questionnaire; other candidates, Charles J Hynes and James L Larocca, tackle series of other issues; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For Bill Clinton, as for all Presidents, the White House has been a stage, the symbol of national power and executive authority, its stately rooms reflecting America's noblest aspirations. In the Oval Office, he has met foreign leaders like Boris Yeltsin and Yitzhak Rabin and pondered domestic issues like health care and welfare. He has also used the elegant setting for less lofty purposes, as a political platform and as a place to charm the rich and powerful for campaign contributions or votes.

headline.main: 10 Days in the White House: Public Acts, Private Moments

docs.abstract: Chronology of 10 sexual encounters between former White House intern Monica S Lewinsky and Pres Clinton, between November 1995 and March 1997, as contained in report to Congress by independent counsel, Kenneth W Starr; Clinton wove encounters with Lewinsky into sessions for bill signings, state dinners and meetings with Government officials and foreign dignitaries; their meetings apparently amounted to less than 10 hours over 16 months--even though Lewinsky's life was apparently dominated by her obsession with President; photos (L)
docs.snippet: For Bill Clinton, as for all Presidents, the White House has been a stage, the symbol of national power and executive authority, its stately rooms reflecting America's noblest aspirations. In the Oval Office, he has met foreign leaders like Boris...

byline.original: BY ROBERT D. MCFADDEN, JOHN KIFNER AND N. R. KLEINFIELD

docs.lead_paragraph: Perusing video release schedules for the fall and winter, one finds an unusually large number of finely realized little films scattered among the more ham-fisted blockbusters. Parity may not be the word, but about a dozen critically praised and well-attended art-house movies are about to stage the same kind of modest breakout on videotape that they had during generally solid runs in theaters this spring and summer. Many of them come from so-called art-film divisions of big studios that are willing to give their better-performing little movies a nod even while stoking the fortunes of their mega-properties.
docs.abstract: Home Video column takes note of several small gems among recent releases; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Contraception, Three Days After'' (editorial, Sept. 4): By stating that unlike abortion pills, ''emergency contraception pills cannot end a pregnancy,'' you wrongly imply that conception does not occur at the moment of fertilization, but only after the fertilized egg implants in the uterine wall. These ''morning after'' pills in no way assuage those who oppose abortion.
docs.abstract: Letter from Rev Michael P Orsi, assistant chancellor of Diocese of Camden, disputes September 4 editorial lauding FDA's approval of emergency contraception pills that women can take three days after sex to prevent pregnancy; says such morning-after pills do not assuage those who oppose abortion (S)
